thread.title: Ancient Paris quarry offers off-limits look at city's underground history [Photos]
thread.title_full: Ancient Paris quarry offers off-limits look at city's underground history [Photos]

title: Ancient Paris quarry offers off-limits look at city's underground history [Photos]
text:
Maggy Donaldson, THE ASSOCIATED PRESS First posted: Thursday, August 06, 2015 10:21 AM CDT Paris quarry Previous Next 
Shadows of journalists pass on a gallery wall during a press visit in an underground stone quarry under the Bois de Vincennes park in the southeast of Paris on August 5, 2015. The stone quarry, in use until the end of the 19th century for the exploitation of construction stones of Parisian buildings, is normally closed to the public for safety reasons. AFP PHOTO / HUGO MATHY AFP 
A picture taken on August 5, 2015 shows a graffity on a gallery in an underground stone quarry under the Bois de Vincennes park in the southeast of Paris. The stone quarry, in use until the end of the 19th century for the exploitation of construction stones of Parisian buildings, is normally closed to the public for safety reasons. AFP PHOTO / HUGO MATHY AFP 
A journalist walks through a corridor during a press visit of an underground stone quarry under the Bois de Vincennes park in the southeast of Paris on August 5, 2015. The stone quarry, in use until the end of the 19th century for the exploitation of construction stones of Parisian buildings, is normally closed to the public for safety reasons. AFP PHOTO / HUGO MATHY AFP 
Visitors tour the depths of the Vincennes quarry during a press visit, near Paris, France, Wednesday Aug. 5, 2015. The tunnels zigzagging through limestone were created to provide building materials for Paris. Then they became the damp home to vast subterranean mushroom farms. Now, deep beneath the city�s largest park, the quarry is usually off-limits, deemed too dangerous for regular visitors. Unescorted spelunkers face a 60-euro ($65) fine, but on Wednesday the 20-meter (66-foot) spiral staircase leading down into the earth from the Bois de Vincennes park was briefly opened to journalists. (AP Photo/Jacques Brinon) AP 
Visitors tour the depths of the Vincennes quarry during a press visit, near Paris, France, Wednesday Aug. 5, 2015. The tunnels zigzagging through limestone were created to provide building materials for Paris. Then they became the damp home to vast subterranean mushroom farms. Now, deep beneath the city�s largest park, the quarry is usually off-limits, deemed too dangerous for regular visitors. Unescorted spelunkers face a 60-euro ($65) fine, but on Wednesday the 20-meter (66-foot) spiral staircase leading down into the earth from the Bois de Vincennes park was briefly opened to journalists. (AP Photo/Jacques Brinon) AP 
A journalist looks at a stone pillar called a totem used to support the ceiling during a press visit in an underground stone quarry under the Bois de Vincennes park in the southeast of Paris on August 5, 2015. The stone quarry, in use until the end of the 19th century for the exploitation of construction stones of Parisian buildings, is normally closed to the public for safety reasons. AFP PHOTO / HUGO MATHY AFP
